items.message:
River levels continue to remain high on Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon and Dauntsey Brook and the Sherston Avon. The unsettled weather continues, further showery rain is expected today, Sunday the 19th November, which will continue to maintain high river levels. No Flood Warnings are currently forecast to be issued in this Flood Alert area. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated on Monday morning, or sooner if the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Lower Dorset Frome due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated byÂ 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are steady on the River Thame as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thame, Stadhampton, and Dorchester areas. A band of rain is expected this morning 20/11/23, with isolated showers throughout the day and overnight. The outlook for the rest of the week has improved. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Mersey catchment including areas near Bramhall, Stockport, Sale, Altrincham and Urmston

floodArea.county: Cheshire East, Manchester, Salford, Stockport, Tameside, Trafford, Warrington

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed. As a result, there is no longer a flood warning in the area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River levels remain high in the River Rye catchment due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include land around the River Rye and it's tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck, Spittle Beck, including properties of Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.
This flood alert has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern. We continue to closely follow the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to recent rainfall.

Areas most at risk include the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible in these areas.

Further light rainfall is forecast over the weekend before an improved forecast for early next week.

The Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and Lake Windermere will remain high today, but we do not expect any flooding to properties.

We will continue to monitor levels closely over the weekend.

Newby Bridge sluices remain open due to high lake levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Lake levels on Derwent Water and river levels in Borrowdale remain high due to recent rainfall.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and low lying areas in Borrowdale.

River and lake levels are expected to remain high throughout Saturday and into Sunday.

Further light rainfall is forecast on Saturday and Sunday before the forecast improves early in the week.

We will continue to monitor levels closely over the weekend.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Lake levels on Derwent Water remain high due to recent rainfall.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.

Lake levels are expected to remain high throughout Saturday and into Sunday.

Further light rainfall is forecast on Saturday and Sunday keeping lake levels high at the Lodore gauge.

We will continue to monitor levels closely over the weekend.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but falling at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on Monday, 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels on the Upper River Aire catchment have fallen below levels of concern. We do not expect any significant rain over the next few days. This flood alert is therefore no longer in force. We will continue to monitor the situation.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected along riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith and South Esplanade. We expect levels to stay high today, Monday 20/11/23 and then begin falling again overnight. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 7pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.
This flood alert has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern. There is further rain forecast for the next few days and we will reissue this alert if necessary.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include the upper Derwent areas, land around Old Malton, Low Marishes and Priorpot Beck in Norton. Levels are expected to remain high for a few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high on the lower River Derwent due to recent heavy rain. Areas most at risk include local roads and low-lying land around Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. Levels are expected to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please monitor local weather and river conditions and avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
The forecast is for drier weather for this coming week, although showers are still possible for today, Monday 20/11/2023.
The Washford River remains high but is falling and is not expected to rise again over the next few days. There may remain some limited flooding of low-lying land and roads in and around the Washford River. The Horner Water, River Aller, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream and Doniford Stream are now back to normal winter base flow levels. We expect to remove this Flood Warning later today or on Tuesday.
Please consider the weather conditions and local water levels and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor the river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens.
This message will be updated by 11am on 21/11/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk of flooding are around the River Foulness. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we expect levels to remain high. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 11am on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham
items.message: River levels remain high on Broadlane Beck and Creyke Beck due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include properties around King Street, Northgate, Dunswell Road and North Moor Lane. This means properties are at risk of flooding. Further showers are forecast and we expect levels to remain high today, Monday 20/11/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull

items.message: River levels remain high in the Cottingham area due to recent rainfall. The areas most at risk include Cottingham, Kirk Ella, Anlaby and Hessle. Levels are steady, however, further rain has fallen and we expect levels to remain high today, Monday 20/11/23. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated at 7pm on 20/11/23 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.34 m and is slowly falling. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 5.74 m and is slowly falling. 
A small amount of rain fell overnight and some showers are forecast during Sunday and into Monday but weather is improving and drier conditions are forecast from Tuesday onwards. 
We continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels closely and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens.  
We are pumping at Currymoor and Saltmoor pumping stations when river levels allow and have deployed additional temporary pumps at both stations and at Elsonâs Clyce. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 1pm on Monday 20 November.

River levels have risen at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the weekend.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Actual peak:- Llanymynach 4.0 m overnight Sunday.  

Further scattered showers are forecast for Monday. It will become more settled and drier for the remainder of the week.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.   

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued by the Environment Agency. 

Flood Alert in force: Lower Avon and tributaries. 

Flooding is possible for: Tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.    

Be prepared.

 River levels are high but steady at the Ringwood Old Cottage river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated Wednesday, 22/11/23, or as the situation changes. 

To check the latest information for your area

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are slowly falling on the River Blackwater and The Cove Brook. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing. This morning's 20/11/23 rain will gradually clear to leave a mostly dry day. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening 20/11/23 or if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels have fallen following recent rainfall but levels in York remain high. Areas most at risk include the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. We don't expect levels to rise again significantly, however, we don't expect levels in York to begin falling until tonight, Monday 20/11/23. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 7pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Sunday 19th November 2023. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas on the Deben from Debenham to Ufford, including Framsden, Earl Soham, Easton, Glevering and Wickham Market, and on the Rivers Lark and Finn around Witnesham, Tuddenham St Martin, Playford and Grundisburgh. The forecast is for scattered showers today, Sunday 19th November. Further scattered showers are forecast for tomorrow. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Monday 20th November, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high and steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall during the past week.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.    

Further scattered showers are forecast for Monday. It will become more settled and drier for the remainder of the week.   

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.   

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Sunday 19th November. Water levels continue to remain high and may last for the next few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent rainfall across the area. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. The weather forecast is for scattered showers today, Sunday 19th November. Further scattered showers are forecast for tomorrow. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Monday 20th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Sunday 19th November 2023. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth, Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. The forecast is for scattered showers today, Sunday 19th November. Further scattered showers are forecast for tomorrow. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Monday 20th November, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels continue to remain high on the Bristol Avon at Bradford-on-Avon and the Semington Brook at Semington. Further light showery rainfall is expected today, Sunday 19th November. No Flood Warnings are currently forecast to be issued in this Flood Alert area. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated on Monday morning, or sooner if the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Shardlow river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall yesterday.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day 20/11/23.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.

This message will be updated by 5:00pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of rainfall over the weekend. Further scattered showers are forecast for Monday. It will become more settled and drier for the remainder of the week. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 5.5m to 5.7m Monday evening, Montford 4.7m to 5.0m Tuesday morning, Welshbridge 2.5m to 2.8m Tuesday afternoon, Buildwas 3.5m to 4.0m Wednesday.    
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00am on 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling, on the River Thames as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Abingdon and Culham areas. A band of rain is expected this morning 20/11/23, with isolated showers throughout the day and overnight. The outlook for the rest of the week has improved. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar are high but falling slowly. No rain has been recorded in the last 24 hours, which is enabling river levels to recover. In the last 30 days, 380mm of rain has been recorded at Knighton. This is almost half (47%) of the expected annual total (814mm). The level at Alverstone is falling by about 2cm each hour. The level at Sandown peaked at 05:00 today (19/11/2023), and is falling at about 1cm per hour. A small amount of rain (10mm) is forecast for Monday night (20/11/2023). We do not expect any further impacts based on this forecast, but it could prolong the current high water levels. Ditches surrounding Fort Holiday Park in Sandown could remain full for the next few days. This Flood Alert will remain in force until the river level measured at Sandown has fallen to 1.07mAOD and minor impacts are no longer expected. We will continue to manage the water level at Bembridge and monitor the forecast. This message will be updated or removed by 15:00 on 20/11/2023.

items.message:

River levels remain high but are slowly falling on the Chertsey Bourne. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue, especially in the Chertsey area. This morning's 20/11/23 rain will gradually clear to leave a mostly dry day. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Slad Brook from Upper Steanbridge Mill to Rowcroft, Stroud
items.message:
River levels are high but steady as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and adjacent land is expected in the next few hours.  We expect flooding to affect Flood Warning for The Vatch - fast flowing increased water levels may impact properties in The Vatch. Install Property level protection if required. Monitor the brook for further increases   
Consequently flooding could occur in the next few hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and or Local Authorities.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss and the River Dove to Ellingham, including Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely throughout today, Sunday 19th November 2023. River levels remain higher than normal after the rainfall yesterday. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Diss, Eye, Harleston and Bungay. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for light rain this afternoon, Sunday 19th November. Tomorrow is due to be a drier day but there may be some passing showers.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Monday 20th November.

The Cuckmere River remains high but is slowly falling. Only minimal flood impacts will continue to affect fields and rural roads in both Hellingly and Alfriston. Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). River levels are expected to fall, but could rise again on Monday. However, levels are not expected to reach those seen on Saturday (18/11/2023). The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of property flooding increases.

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling, on the River Churn as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Cerney Wick area. A band of rain is expected this morning 20/11/23, with isolated showers throughout the day and overnight. The outlook for the rest of the week has improved. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling, on the River Thames as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially between the Buscot Wick and Eynsham areas. A band of rain is expected this morning 20/11/23, with isolated showers throughout the day and overnight. The outlook for the rest of the week has improved. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in York as a result of recent rainfall. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, particularly around properties along Queens Staith on South Esplanade, Friars Terrace and Tower Place, St Georges Field car parks and Rowntree Park. Levels in York at the Viking recorder are currently around 3.1m. We expect levels to stay around this today, Monday 20/11/23 and begin falling again overnight. We will continue to monitor the forecast. The Foss Barrier is being operated. Please monitor local water levels and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in York in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect riverside properties, properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Levels in York at the Viking recorder are currently around 3.1m. We expect levels to stay around this today, Monday 20/11/23 and begin falling again overnight. The Foss Barrier is in operation. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: The Western Rother remains high in Fittleworth, but is slowly falling. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads could continue in Fittleworth. Elsewhere on the Western Rother, river levels are falling and no impacts are expected. River levels in Fittleworth will increase slightly on Monday afternoon (20/11/2023) following rain showers this morning. However, levels are expected to be lower than those seen on Saturday evening (18/11/2023). Settled weather with occasional light showers are forecast from Tuesday (21/11/2023) to Thursday (23/11/2023). River levels will reduce all along the Western Rother. River levels in Fittleworth could be higher than normal all week. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of property flooding increases.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising slowly on the River Cherwell as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible later this evening 20/11/23, especially in the Thrupp area. A band of rain is expected this morning 20/11/23, with isolated showers throughout the day and overnight. The outlook for the rest of the week has improved. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling, on the River Thames as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Wolvercote and Botley areas. A band of rain is expected this morning 20/11/23, with isolated showers throughout the day and overnight. The outlook for the rest of the week has improved. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, some areas of Durban Road, fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, as well as caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The Barnham Rife is slowly rising following showers on Monday morning (20/11/2023), but it is not expected to reach the levels seen on Saturday (19/11/2023). Flood impacts continue in Bersted. Settled weather with occasional light showers are forecast from Tuesday (21/11/2023) to Thursday (23/11/2023). Water levels should start to reduce, but will remain higher than normal for the rest of the week. The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 on 21/11/2023.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station (HEPS) is 7.97 m and is slowly falling. The drain level at HEPS is 7.82 m and is steady.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m.
A small amount of rain fell overnight and some showers are forecast during Sunday and into Monday but weather is improving and drier conditions are forecast from Tuesday onwards. 
When river levels allow, pumping continues at Huish Episcopi and we are utilising the Parrett Relief Channel to evacuate water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. This message will be updated by 1pm on Monday 20/11/2023.
Please consider local water levels and weather conditions and do not walk or drive through flood water.
For water levels on the River Yeo and the drain at HEPS please refer to our website: (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).

The Combe Haven in Bulverhythe remains high and will continue to rise by 30cm over each high tide period. Flooding could continue to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground, and possibly some gardens on Bexhill Road in Bulverhythe. River levels in Crowhurst have fallen from Saturday's peak. Only minimal flood impacts are expected in Crowhurst. Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). River levels are expected to fall, but could rise again on Monday. However, levels are not expected to reach those seen on Saturday (18/11/2023). The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Please remain prepared for flood risk to return this winter. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of property flooding increases.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high, but slowly falling. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, some areas of Durban Road, fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, as well as caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Scattered showers are forecast on Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). River levels are expected to fall, but could rise again on Monday. However, levels are not expected to reach those seen on Saturday (18/11/2023). With the rest of November forecast to remain unsettled, the Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will re-issue this message if the risk of property flooding increases.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
A small amount of rain fell overnight and some showers are forecast during Sunday and into Monday but weather is improving and drier conditions are forecast from Tuesday onwards. 
This Flood Alert remains in force due to the flooding of large areas of the Somerset Levels and Moors. Flood water may affect the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road, and the road and properties at the south end of Westover Trading Estate.
We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. This message will be updated by 1 pm on Monday 20/11/2023.

River levels are rising slowly on the River Derwent due to rainfall over the weekend. Flooding remains a risk near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Buttercrambe Mill at Buttercrambe Bridge. Further showers are forecast and we expect expect levels to remain high today, Monday 20/11/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Derwent at Stamford Bridge - The Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: River levels are rising slowly on the River Derwent due to rainfall over the weekend. The area most at risk is around River Derwent at Stamford Bridge - The Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge. We expect levels to remain high today, Monday 20/11/23 and further showers are forecast. Please consider putting your flood plan into action and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message by 3pm on 20/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high at Frodingham Beck and on the River Hull due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include the upper Hull area including Kilham, Nafferton, Driffield, Bainton, North Dalton, Leconfield, Leven, Brandesburton, North Frodingham and Beeford. Further showers are forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 20/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  

It is forecast to be largely dry this evening and overnight 19/11/23. We will continue to monitor the forecast. We have been checking the condition of defences and clearing debris from weed screens.  

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

River levels are remaining high on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, River Nadder.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, River Nadder, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood.
Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow morning.
River levels are remaining high.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: River Thames for Henley, Remenham, Medmenham and its tributaries

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Oxfordshire, Windsor and Maidenhead, Wokingham
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Assendon Stream, Hambledon Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are slowly falling on the River Thames at Henley, Renmenham and Medmenham. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing. This morning's 20/11/23 rain will gradually clear to leave a mostly dry day. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening 20/11/23, or if the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of property flooding. Water remains on Curry Moor and Hay Moor and we continue to pump water to reduce levels further. For information, the River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.02m and the drain level at Currymoor is 5.48m.
The forecast is for drier weather for this coming week, although showers are still possible for today, Monday 20/11/2023. 
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: A gradual easing of conditions over the past week is likely to be reversed following a fresh band of heavy rain in the next 24 hours. We do not expect property flooding at this stage, but some roads, including from Winterborne Abbas to Winterborne Came are likely to be flooded once more. Avoid driving through flood water if at all possible as your bow wave can cause damage to nearby homes. EA staff will continue to monitor the situation locally and will update this message should the situation change.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have remained high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days. Groundwater levels in the area are currently stable but remain responsive to rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain.

Groundwater level will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 25/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Piddle.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham from 09:00 AM on 18/11/2023.
Further light rainfall is forecast this afternoon.
River levels are high but steady, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message: A gradual easing of conditions over the past week is likely to be reversed following a fresh band of heavy rain in the next 24 hours. We do not expect property flooding at this stage, but some roads, including Stubhampton to Tarrant Hinton, Farnham to Gussage St Andrew and Wyke Down to Monkton up Wimborne are likely to be impassable once more. Avoid driving through flood water if at all possible as your bow wave can cause damage to nearby homes. EA staff will continue to monitor the situation locally and will update this message should the situation change.

The River Lavant remains high. Minimal flood impacts are expected which could affect fields, rural roads and gardens between West Dean and Westhampnett. In East Lavant, water may affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green, and possibly access bridges over the river. Flood water could affect gardens and approach properties at The Sadlers, Westhampnett. River levels will increase slightly following rain on Monday morning (20/11/2023). However, levels are expected to be lower than those seen on Saturday (18/11/2023). Settled weather with occasional light showers are forecast from Tuesday (21/11/2023) to Thursday (23/11/2023). Water levels will remain higher than normal and the river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall. Some roads could be affected by flood water. Plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Sheepwash Lane. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are managing structures in Westhampnett to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 on 21/11/2023.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling, on the River Leach as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, 20/11/23, especially in the Lechlade area. A band of rain is expected this morning 20/11/23, with isolated showers throughout the day and overnight. The outlook for the rest of the week has improved. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on Bielby Beck due to recent rainfall. River levels are currently steady, below the expected threshold for property flooding and are starting to fall; however, further showers are forecast for the next few days. Please consider putting your flood plan into action and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message by 3pm 20/11/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hurley to Cookham
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are slowly falling on the River Thames from Hurley to Cookham. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing. This morning's 20/11/23 rain will gradually clear to leave a mostly dry day. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening 20/11/23, or if the situation changes.
